qas.question: Who was the Air Officer Commanding Fighter Command after 1940?
What strategy could the German's have used instead of day raids?
Why were civic and political leaders worried about Dowdings?

answers.text: lack of reaction to the new crisis

context: In the inter-war years and after 1940, <a0_0>Hugh Dowding<a0_0/>, Air Officer Commanding Fighter Command has received credit for the <a1_0>defence of British air space<a1_0/> and the failure of the Luftwaffe to achieve air superiority. However, Dowding had spent so much effort preparing day fighter defences, there was little to prevent the Germans carrying out an alternative strategy by <a2_0>bombing at night<a2_0/>. When the Luftwaffe struck at British cities for the first time on 7 September 1940, a number of civic and political leaders were worried by Dowding's apparent <a3_0>lack of reaction to the new crisis<a3_0/>.
